<p><strong>The COVID-19 pandemic</strong> and a national reckoning on racial injustice in the United States in 2020 drew attention to many disparities among Americans, including access to healthcare and outcomes in health. Those gaps continue to exist including for individuals who work for large US employers.</p>
<p>Health equity in the workplace means that all employees have a fair and just opportunity to be as healthy as possible.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8f3ff366-bf2a-4bd5-9292-f2b80d1a1d44"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8f3ff366-bf2a-4bd5-9292-f2b80d1a1d44" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Achieving health equity,” Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, rwjf.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Large employers have long offered employer-sponsored health insurance, but now many are asking what more they can do to help employees access the healthcare and other benefits they need.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Survey methodology</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Findings in this article are based on responses to the 2021 McKinsey Health Equity in the Workplace Survey, which was fielded in June 2021. Respondents formed a nationally representative sample of 2,905 full-time employees of large employers (defined as those with more than 500 employees) between the ages of 18 and 84. The survey sample was weighted to reflect national demographics. Respondents who were not eligible for employee benefits through their employer were excluded from analysis. Survey data were supplemented with qualitative data from ten focus groups of employees at large US-based employers, as well as from interviews with HR professionals and leading experts in health equity. Survey respondents and focus-group participants were asked about the following:</p>

<ul>
    <li>their social and physical context (for example, self-rated health, work environment, and ability to meet basic needs)</li>
    <li>their access to and awareness of employer benefits</li>
    <li>their utilization of benefits</li>
    <li>their experience of healthcare interactions</li>
    <li>health- and work-related outcomes (for example, perception of employer benefits and absenteeism)</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>To offer guidance on that question, we analyzed data from a June 2021 survey of full-time employees at large US employers across multiple industries to understand the state of health equity within the American workforce (see sidebar “Survey methodology”). Our survey results indicate that employees of large US employers, even those earning high salaries, face healthcare disparities. For example, Black, Hispanic and Latino, Asian, and LGBTQ+ individuals were less likely to report receiving the care they needed and were more likely than the overall employee population to report considering switching employers for reasons related to benefits.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="69f8046e-1c17-4b04-b28b-1ee44f9db798"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="69f8046e-1c17-4b04-b28b-1ee44f9db798" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In this report, LGBTQ+ refers to respondents who self-identified as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, pansexual, or questioning.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>To improve health equity, employers can take action in three areas:</p>
<ul>
    <li>expand benefits that help employees to meet basic needs (for example, housing and transportation)</li>
    <li>ensure benefits are easy to access, understand, and use</li>
    <li>change workplace culture to destigmatize receiving care</li>
</ul>
<p>By taking action to support health equity among employees, employers can not only build a healthier and more productive workforce but also improve employee retention, broaden impact on families over generations, and help create a more just society. Additionally, increased engagement could help employers defray long-term costs.</p>
<h2>Lack of accessible or affordable care can prompt employees to consider searching for a new job</h2>
<p>Research indicates that diverse teams often make better decisions and that there is a correlation between diverse organizations and outperformance.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="752ee61f-61c7-4000-a457-b549faa45625"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="752ee61f-61c7-4000-a457-b549faa45625" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Heidi Grant, Jacqui Grey, and David Rock, “Diverse teams feel less comfortable — and that’s why they perform better,” <em>Harvard Business Review</em>, September 22, 2016, hbr.org.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="620ba5fd-e4e2-4744-98c7-53ae143789a4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="620ba5fd-e4e2-4744-98c7-53ae143789a4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sundiatu Dixon-Fyle, Kevin Dolan, Vivian Hunt, and Sara Prince, “<a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters">Diversity wins: How inclusion matters</a>,” May 19, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Our survey found, however, that employers are at greater risk of losing diverse talent due to challenges these employees face in using benefits to meet their needs. In our survey, 30 percent or more of Black, Hispanic and Latino, LGBTQ+, and younger employees said they had considered switching employers due to their health benefits, even when they had access to the same benefits as other colleagues (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95420cc5-120a-4bd6-a809-b864a1f8b618"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95420cc5-120a-4bd6-a809-b864a1f8b618" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Younger defined as those age 40 and below.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, employees who reported not receiving the care they needed were two times more likely to consider switching employers and half as likely to say they would recommend their employer to friends based on benefits (Exhibit 1). These data points suggest that health equity is an important element to consider as employers create and evaluate their talent value propositions.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="More than a third of Black, Hispanic and Latino, LGBTQ+, and younger employees have considered switching employers for better health benefits." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Health insurance and related services are typically the largest non-salary benefits employees receive. They also influence employee sentiment and feelings of inclusion. Benefits can help employees feel cared for and supported by their employer, even outside of the workplace. In our survey, diverse employees were less likely to report feeling that their current benefits showed that their employer cared about them. LGBTQ+ respondents, for example, were 1.6 times less likely to report feeling their current benefits showed that their employer cared.</p>
<p>Inequity in employees’ ability to find, receive, and afford care for themselves and their dependents can also lead to groups of employees missing work more often or feeling less productive at work. Our survey found that people of color were more likely to report missing six or more days of work for health reasons than White respondents.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e86d8237-1a96-40e6-8345-260d47706d31"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e86d8237-1a96-40e6-8345-260d47706d31" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In this report, we use “people of color” to refer to individuals who self-identify as Black, Hispanic and Latino, Asian, or Indigenous.</span></span></span></a></span> If Black, Hispanic and Latino, and Asian employees were able to meet their own health needs and those of their dependents while missing the same average number of days as White employees, the US economy could expand by around $20 billion—the equivalent of between 5 and 10 percent of the total cost of absenteeism, as estimated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7443ce87-ebd7-4d1e-94d7-44e3590057e3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7443ce87-ebd7-4d1e-94d7-44e3590057e3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In 2015, the CDC estimated that productivity losses linked to absenteeism cost employers around $225.8 billion annually, or the equivalent of $1,625 per worker per year.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<h3>Expand benefits that help employees meet basic needs</h3>
<p>The ability to meet basic needs (for example, housing, transportation, social support, and economic stability) affects health and well-being. McKinsey’s Consumer Social Determinants of Health Survey found that individuals with a greater number of unmet basic needs often have decreased access to healthcare and lower satisfaction with the care they do receive.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8c32271f-f550-43d3-8f1b-f09dfd1f3be0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8c32271f-f550-43d3-8f1b-f09dfd1f3be0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In 2015, the CDC estimated that productivity losses linked to absenteeism cost employers around $225.8 billion annually, or the equivalent of $1,625 per worker per year.</span></span></span></a></span> Our survey underscores these findings, as employees with one or more unmet basic needs were around 2.4 times more likely to have not received needed physical healthcare (Exhibit 2) and to have missed six or more days of work in the past 12 months (Exhibit 3).</p>

<p>We found that around 65 percent of all full-time employees of large US employers had experienced at least one unmet basic need, and 66 percent of LGBTQ+ employees experienced two or more unmet basic needs (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="73ca6c15-2c64-4d10-9a87-cf6a618e1628"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="73ca6c15-2c64-4d10-9a87-cf6a618e1628" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Survey was conducted during the COVID-19 pandemic, likely leading to higher levels of unmet social support due to factors such as quarantines, lockdowns, and physical distancing. Basic needs include social support, economic stability, community safety, employment, housing, food security, transportation, education, and personal safety.</span></span></span></a></span> Even when controlling for income, disparities existed for people of color: 69 percent of employees of color earning less than $100,000 in household income experienced two or more unmet basic needs in the past year, compared to 49 percent of White employees in the same income bracket.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit-4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Black, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ workers were most likely to say they struggled to meet basic needs over the past year." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit-4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Some groups also experience specific unmet basic needs more acutely than others. For instance, Black, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ people reported economic instability and a lack of social support, while Asian employees reported concerns over community safety.</p>
<p>The relatively high share of employees with unmet basic needs highlights an opportunity for employers to provide additional benefits to close these gaps. Many employers recognize that employees with lower wages may struggle to pay for food, transportation, and healthcare. As one HR professional said in a survey response, “Our frontline employees have trouble balancing paying for benefits with paying for immediate needs like childcare and food.” One insurance company recently took steps to help employees balance their budgets by providing them with employer-funded debit cards that can be used to pay for food, transportation, or childcare. Others provide discounted legal services to help employees with housing, safety, or immigration needs; partner with local communities to provide subsidized transportation or housing; or offer on-site subsidized childcare to help employees meet their basic needs.</p>
<h3>Ensure that benefits are easy to access, understand, and use</h3>
<p>Interviews with HR and employee-benefits teams suggest that many large employers have room to improve how they inform employees of their available benefits and in making those benefits easy to access, understand, and use. For example, many HR teams said they recognize that emails about benefits often go unread, that employees may not have time to attend informational sessions during work hours, that employees may not have access to internal systems outside of work hours, and that spouses may not have access to these systems at all. Identifying solutions to these communication challenges can be difficult given operating models or technology constraints. Some HR professionals have used creative solutions to better engage employees, such as sending postcards to employees’ home addresses as an additional channel for mass communications or using employee resource groups and diverse leaders from across the organization to communicate important benefits-related messages. Still, many HR departments find themselves relying on ad hoc, one-on-one communications to employees with the greatest needs.</p>
<p>When companies partner with vendors and payers (such as insurance companies) to make benefits easy to understand and navigate, employees are more likely to be able to receive the care they need. Our survey results show that diverse employees across income levels are more likely to say they do not qualify for or are not sure if they qualify for major benefits, such as health insurance, ancillary insurance, employee assistance programs, leave policies, and wellness benefits. Diverse colleagues were also more likely to report finding tools and resources provided to explain benefits unhelpful in answering their questions. For example, employees of color were 1.4 to 1.5 times more likely than White employees to find the resources and tools explaining benefits unhelpful, even at the highest income levels (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit_5-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Employees of color at all income levels were more likely to find resources explaining health benefits to be unhelpful." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit_5-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The root causes of this discrepancy likely vary. For instance, LGBTQ+ focus-group participants shared that they could easily find resources on fertility benefits for heterosexual couples. However, they were not sure if those benefits also applied to same-sex couples, often because the resources lacked inclusive language around gender and sexuality. Employees who are immigrants or children of immigrants said that resources often assumed an understanding of complicated details about the US healthcare system and that, in times when they needed care the most, they did not have time or mental space to research nuances concerning what applied to them. One employee commented, “My family is coming from a country that had a different [healthcare] system, and now I’m put into this situation where I have to figure it out on my own and I don’t have a support group to lean on.” In short, materials and websites explaining benefits need to be centralized and easy to navigate, and they also need to resonate with different audiences.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Diversity wins: How inclusion matters" src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/diversity%20and%20inclusion/diversity%20wins%20how%20inclusion%20matters/diversity-wins-tetris_render10-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Diversity wins: How inclusion matters</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the report</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Employers can take a number of steps to improve the accessibility of employee resources and benefits, including (but not limited to) the following initiatives:</p>
<h3>Use inclusive language</h3>
<p>Many employees reported confusion when trying to understand which benefits they were eligible for and how to use them. Employers may consider carefully reviewing their benefits resources and ensure inclusivity in their communications. Although many of these materials are produced by health insurance companies, employers can partner with carriers to incorporate inclusive language in forms and other materials. This may include using gender-neutral language when describing parental leave or health benefits, as well as considering translating resources into a wide range of languages. Both of these steps could help ensure employees from all backgrounds have equal opportunities to understand and use their benefits.</p>
<h3>Enhance the availability of personalized information</h3>
<p>Diverse employees were especially likely to report experiencing moments of “frustration” when accessing healthcare, citing unexpected costs and “not feeling listened to” as key factors.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="42e20e18-1e03-40d2-b7c3-d157781681b8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="42e20e18-1e03-40d2-b7c3-d157781681b8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Respondents were asked, “In your experience receiving healthcare in the last two years, [have you had] a moment that significantly frustrated you when you interacted with a healthcare company or provider?”</span></span></span></a></span> To help employees anticipate medical costs, employers could provide tools that estimate out-of-pocket costs for copays and deductibles. Employers could also consider implementing care-coordination services to help their employees have better healthcare experiences.</p>
<h3>Support through culturally competent providers</h3>
<p>Care-coordination services guide and support employees in understanding their benefits, including estimating costs and finding providers who understand employees’ backgrounds and experiences. Collectively, care coordination may improve employee experience within the healthcare system and increases the likelihood that patients receive the care they need. One Asian employee said she wanted to find doctors who would understand and not invalidate her experiences, most notably after one doctor suggested that “Asian women don’t have a high pain tolerance.” One LGBTQ+ employee discussed spending hours outside of work finding a primary care provider (PCP) who would offer a welcoming environment to their family of two moms and a child: “I didn’t want someone who would just assume my child has a dad and ask about ‘their father’s health history.’” Care coordinators can help employees find providers who may be better suited to their personal or economic needs, saving the employee valuable time, and helping fend off frustration.</p>
<p>Similarly, employers can also encourage their employees to seek care from a PCP.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="518dca6d-c86d-44a2-a1cc-9b7874ae493c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="518dca6d-c86d-44a2-a1cc-9b7874ae493c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In our survey, interviews, and focus groups, “PCPs” encompass any clinician (for example, doctors, nurse practitioners, and physician assistants) who could provide, coordinate, or help a patient access a range of healthcare services.</span></span></span></a></span> Employees who said they had a preferred PCP were more likely to have had “delightful” healthcare experiences; employees of color in particular were around eleven percentage points more likely to have had “delightful” experiences if they had a PCP (Exhibit 6).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bdbcebf6-808d-4044-9133-d113f5d51ead"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bdbcebf6-808d-4044-9133-d113f5d51ead" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Respondents were asked, “Do you have a preferred clinic or doctor’s office you visit for physical exams or if you are sick or injured?”</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea79e122-dede-4a6c-b57f-7f2d77ca3bbf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea79e122-dede-4a6c-b57f-7f2d77ca3bbf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Respondents were asked, “In your experience receiving healthcare in the last two years, [have you had] a moment that significantly delighted you when you interacted with a healthcare company or provider?”</span></span></span></a></span> LGBTQ+ employees were 30 percentage points more likely to have had “delightful” experiences. By encouraging—and even providing incentives for—employees to build relationships with PCPs and by giving them the needed resources to find PCPs who understand and validate personal identities and experiences, employers may be able to improve their employees’ healthcare experiences, helping them receive the care they need.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit-6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Workers with a primary clinician were more likely to have positive healthcare experiences, particularly for employees of color and LGBTQ+ employees." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/income%20alone%20may%20be%20insufficient/svg-employerhealth-exhibit-6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Bring benefits to life</h3>
<p>Employees could also benefit from seeing how others are actually using their benefits. HR can help by offering spotlights of real employees or employee archetypes using different benefits, including leaders with diverse profiles, in the hope that employees may identify with others who “look like them.” HR can also provide supplemental content to health insurance policies to offer more detailed guidance on the use of various benefits (for example, how to find a PCP or how to navigate a pregnancy), as well as information about how to effectively navigate the US healthcare and insurance systems.</p>
<p>Finally, employers can take steps to ensure that their enhanced communications are resonating with multiple audiences. These steps may include surveying employees about their experiences and conducting focus groups to further understand gaps in knowledge or understanding. HR can also partner with employee resource groups and diverse leaders to gain additional insight into preferred terminology and specific needs of diverse groups and reach out directly to specific populations that may be underusing their benefits.</p>
<h3>Build a workplace culture that destigmatizes receiving care</h3>
<p>When asked to describe the level of stigma in the workplace associated with taking time to address physical or mental health needs, 53 percent of all employees shared that they felt at least some degree of stigma around receiving physical care, and 61 percent noted some degree of stigma around receiving mental healthcare.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1dd94826-3741-49f2-9131-3615e4848d83"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1dd94826-3741-49f2-9131-3615e4848d83" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Respondents were asked, “What best describes the level of stigma (negative attitudes or actions people may have toward a person based on their condition or characteristics) for the following in your workplace? 1. Taking time to address physical health needs. 2. Taking time to address mental health needs.”</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, people of color and LGBTQ+ employees were three to ten percentage points more likely to report stigma in their workplace than their White or straight counterparts.</p>
<p>Stigma is a pervasive barrier that can inhibit employees from seeking needed care. Among employees who reported not receiving the physical or mental healthcare they needed, 40 percent said the reason they did not receive care was that they felt stigma, shame, or embarrassment. People who do not receive the care they need have a higher risk of missed detection of preventable or treatable illnesses, of later-stage diagnoses, and of mortality.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="17fd032e-74ca-420f-800a-7d179fc02e25"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="17fd032e-74ca-420f-800a-7d179fc02e25" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anthony Damico, Rachel Garfield, and Kendal Orgera, “The uninsured and the ACA: A primer - key facts about health insurance and the uninsured amidst changes to the Affordable Care Act,” Kaiser Family Foundation, January 25, 2019, kff.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, a recent survey conducted by McKinsey found that close to seven in ten respondents with high stigma levels reported missing at least a day of work because of burnout or stress.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fa4a5825-e9dc-413c-a962-ca22a2e80822"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fa4a5825-e9dc-413c-a962-ca22a2e80822" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Erica Coe, Jenny Cordina, Kana Enomoto, and Nikhil Seshan, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/overcoming-stigma-three-strategies-toward-better-mental-health-in-the-workplace">Overcoming stigma: Three strategies toward better mental health in the workplace</a>,” July 23, 2021, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Reducing the stigma of attending to health needs is an important component of maintaining a healthy and productive workforce.</p>
<p>Black, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ employees felt particularly apprehensive about using some benefits due to worries about stigma and seeming “not committed to work.” One woman of color shared that “sometimes in a work environment you are trying to overcome a stereotype. [If you] need a break to take care of something, you are always afraid you’ll come across as lazy or be passed over for promotion.” Employees with chronic illnesses noted similar concerns and were especially worried that their health conditions would find their way into their performance reviews and affect their chances of promotion or even of keeping their job. In our survey, respondents who had missed more days of work due to their own health or that of their dependents noted higher levels of stigma.</p>
<p>Black, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ employees also noted worse mental health outcomes, likely in part due to the mental and emotional toll that stigma and biases can have.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bd49ae94-fa7b-4a50-9f02-ccaf722753f2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bd49ae94-fa7b-4a50-9f02-ccaf722753f2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Javier Alvarez-Galvez and Antonio Rojas-Garcia, “Measuring the impact of multiple discrimination on depression in Europe,” <em>BMC Public Health</em>, April 25, 2019, Volume 19, Number 435, bmcpublichealth.biomedcentral.com.</span></span></span></a></span> A fifth of Black and Hispanic and Latino and a third of LGBTQ+ employees rated their mental health as “poor,” compared with one-tenth of White employees.</p>
<h2>Fostering a culture of care: Actions to consider</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>While changing a company culture to destigmatize the need for healthcare is difficult, it is a critical step in supporting health equity. Employers can consider several actions along the journey:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Communicate the importance of receiving needed care.</em> Employers can start by modeling inclusive, health-centered behavior and ensuring that workplace norms support health and well-being.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33c9681c-31a8-422a-a346-442c0b645f49"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33c9681c-31a8-422a-a346-442c0b645f49" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Erica Coe, Jenny Cordina, Kana Enomoto, Alex Mandel, and Jeris Stueland, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/national-surveys-reveal-disconnect-between-employees-and-employers-around-mental-health-need">National surveys reveal disconnect between employees and employers around mental health need</a>,” April 21, 2021, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff5e8774-3127-495a-a87c-92859a4f6e5f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff5e8774-3127-495a-a87c-92859a4f6e5f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Erica Coe, Jenny Cordina, Kana Enomoto, and Nikhil Seshan, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/overcoming-stigma-three-strategies-toward-better-mental-health-in-the-workplace">Overcoming stigma: Three strategies toward better mental health in the workplace</a>,” July 23, 2021, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, one company asked senior leaders to sponsor initiatives emphasizing the importance of self-care and mental health, in addition to offering additional benefits such as virtual care and on-demand apps that could provide urgent care when needed.</li>
    <li><em>Train employees on how to support one another in getting the care they need.</em> By investing in employee training on topics such as mental-health first aid, employers can continue to foster workplace community and connectivity.</li>
    <li><em>Improve measurement and accountability.</em> Employers also have an opportunity to use claims or clinical analysis, employee surveys and “pulse checks,” focus groups, lived-experience panels, and holistic assessments of their benefits and programs to monitor their progress against stated health-equity goals.</li>
    <li><em>Allow for more flexible working arrangements.</em> Flexible working styles can reduce stigma and improve employees’ access to care.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f59b504-762e-4584-9bfb-078ce611e2c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f59b504-762e-4584-9bfb-078ce611e2c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Brie Weiler Reynolds, “The mental health benefits of remote and flexible work,” Mental Health America, mhanational.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Many focus group participants said they didn’t feel stigma while working from home during the COVID-19 pandemic because they could attend to their health needs for an hour in the middle of the day while still responding to emails and texts using their phones.</li>
</ol>
<p>Employers can take concrete steps to achieve health equity among their employees, including making benefits easier to understand and navigate, designing new benefits to help employees meet basic needs, and developing a culture that empowers employees to seek needed care without fear of stigma. Employers have a meaningful role to play in improving the health and well-being of their employees. While health equity is first and foremost a human issue, employers that improve access to healthcare for all employees have the opportunity to make real improvements to both employee health and company performance.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/jenny-cordina">Jenny Cordina</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Detroit office, <strong><a href="/our-people/megan-ann-greenfield">Megan Greenfield</a></strong> is a partner in the Boston office, <strong>Lindsay Purcell</strong> is a consultant in the Atlanta office, and <strong>Jeris Stueland</strong> is an associate partner in the Minneapolis office.</p>

Card_content-block__pF6Z1"><span>Article</span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Income alone may be insufficient How employers can help advance health equity in the workplace","displayName":"Income alone may be insufficient How employers can help advance health equity in the workplace","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"f86f4715-4186-4ccc-99da-6962c394ab7d","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Income alone may be insufficient: How employers can help advance health equity in the workplace"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"How employers can help advance health equity in the workplace"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"A recent survey of large US employers found women of color and LGBTQ+ employees have the highest share of unmet basic needs. Employers may consider expanding the range of benefits offered."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"A recent survey of large US employers found women of color and LGBTQ+ employees have the highest share of unmet basic needs."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-12-03T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e and a national reckoning on racial injustice in the United States in 2020 drew attention to many disparities among Americans, including access to healthcare and outcomes in health. Those gaps continue to exist including for individuals who work for large US employers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealth equity in the workplace means that all employees have a fair and just opportunity to be as healthy as possible.[[footnote 1]] Large employers have long offered employer-sponsored health insurance, but now many are asking what more they can do to help employees access the healthcare and other benefits they need.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo offer guidance on that question, we analyzed data from a June 2021 survey of full-time employees at large US employers across multiple industries to understand the state of health equity within the American workforce (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Survey methodology\u0026rdquo;). Our survey results indicate that employees of large US employers, even those earning high salaries, face healthcare disparities. For example, Black, Hispanic and Latino, Asian, and LGBTQ+ individuals were less likely to report receiving the care they needed and were more likely than the overall employee population to report considering switching employers for reasons related to benefits.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo improve health equity, employers can take action in three areas:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eexpand benefits that help employees to meet basic needs (for example, housing and transportation)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eensure benefits are easy to access, understand, and use\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003echange workplace culture to destigmatize receiving care\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy taking action to support health equity among employees, employers can not only build a healthier and more productive workforce but also improve employee retention, broaden impact on families over generations, and help create a more just society. Additionally, increased engagement could help employers defray long-term costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLack of accessible or affordable care can prompt employees to consider searching for a new job\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResearch indicates that diverse teams often make better decisions and that there is a correlation between diverse organizations and outperformance.[[footnote 3]][[footnote 4]] Our survey found, however, that employers are at greater risk of losing diverse talent due to challenges these employees face in using benefits to meet their needs. In our survey, 30 percent or more of Black, Hispanic and Latino, LGBTQ+, and younger employees said they had considered switching employers due to their health benefits, even when they had access to the same benefits as other colleagues (Exhibit 1).[[footnote 5]] In addition, employees who reported not receiving the care they needed were two times more likely to consider switching employers and half as likely to say they would recommend their employer to friends based on benefits (Exhibit 1). These data points suggest that health equity is an important element to consider as employers create and evaluate their talent value propositions.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eHealth insurance and related services are typically the largest non-salary benefits employees receive. They also influence employee sentiment and feelings of inclusion. Benefits can help employees feel cared for and supported by their employer, even outside of the workplace. In our survey, diverse employees were less likely to report feeling that their current benefits showed that their employer cared about them. LGBTQ+ respondents, for example, were 1.6 times less likely to report feeling their current benefits showed that their employer cared.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInequity in employees\u0026rsquo; ability to find, receive, and afford care for themselves and their dependents can also lead to groups of employees missing work more often or feeling less productive at work. Our survey found that people of color were more likely to report missing six or more days of work for health reasons than White respondents.[[footnote 6]] If Black, Hispanic and Latino, and Asian employees were able to meet their own health needs and those of their dependents while missing the same average number of days as White employees, the US economy could expand by around $20 billion\u0026mdash;the equivalent of between 5 and 10 percent of the total cost of absenteeism, as estimated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch3\u003eExpand benefits that help employees meet basic needs\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ability to meet basic needs (for example, housing, transportation, social support, and economic stability) affects health and well-being. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Consumer Social Determinants of Health Survey found that individuals with a greater number of unmet basic needs often have decreased access to healthcare and lower satisfaction with the care they do receive.[[footnote 8]] Our survey underscores these findings, as employees with one or more unmet basic needs were around 2.4 times more likely to have not received needed physical healthcare (Exhibit 2) and to have missed six or more days of work in the past 12 months (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe found that around 65 percent of all full-time employees of large US employers had experienced at least one unmet basic need, and 66 percent of LGBTQ+ employees experienced two or more unmet basic needs (Exhibit 4).[[footnote 9]] Even when controlling for income, disparities existed for people of color: 69 percent of employees of color earning less than $100,000 in household income experienced two or more unmet basic needs in the past year, compared to 49 percent of White employees in the same income bracket.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eSome groups also experience specific unmet basic needs more acutely than others. For instance, Black, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ people reported economic instability and a lack of social support, while Asian employees reported concerns over community safety.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe relatively high share of employees with unmet basic needs highlights an opportunity for employers to provide additional benefits to close these gaps. Many employers recognize that employees with lower wages may struggle to pay for food, transportation, and healthcare. As one HR professional said in a survey response, \u0026ldquo;Our frontline employees have trouble balancing paying for benefits with paying for immediate needs like childcare and food.\u0026rdquo; One insurance company recently took steps to help employees balance their budgets by providing them with employer-funded debit cards that can be used to pay for food, transportation, or childcare. Others provide discounted legal services to help employees with housing, safety, or immigration needs; partner with local communities to provide subsidized transportation or housing; or offer on-site subsidized childcare to help employees meet their basic needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnsure that benefits are easy to access, understand, and use\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterviews with HR and employee-benefits teams suggest that many large employers have room to improve how they inform employees of their available benefits and in making those benefits easy to access, understand, and use. For example, many HR teams said they recognize that emails about benefits often go unread, that employees may not have time to attend informational sessions during work hours, that employees may not have access to internal systems outside of work hours, and that spouses may not have access to these systems at all. Identifying solutions to these communication challenges can be difficult given operating models or technology constraints. Some HR professionals have used creative solutions to better engage employees, such as sending postcards to employees\u0026rsquo; home addresses as an additional channel for mass communications or using employee resource groups and diverse leaders from across the organization to communicate important benefits-related messages. Still, many HR departments find themselves relying on ad hoc, one-on-one communications to employees with the greatest needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen companies partner with vendors and payers (such as insurance companies) to make benefits easy to understand and navigate, employees are more likely to be able to receive the care they need. Our survey results show that diverse employees across income levels are more likely to say they do not qualify for or are not sure if they qualify for major benefits, such as health insurance, ancillary insurance, employee assistance programs, leave policies, and wellness benefits. Diverse colleagues were also more likely to report finding tools and resources provided to explain benefits unhelpful in answering their questions. For example, employees of color were 1.4 to 1.5 times more likely than White employees to find the resources and tools explaining benefits unhelpful, even at the highest income levels (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe root causes of this discrepancy likely vary. For instance, LGBTQ+ focus-group participants shared that they could easily find resources on fertility benefits for heterosexual couples. However, they were not sure if those benefits also applied to same-sex couples, often because the resources lacked inclusive language around gender and sexuality. Employees who are immigrants or children of immigrants said that resources often assumed an understanding of complicated details about the US healthcare system and that, in times when they needed care the most, they did not have time or mental space to research nuances concerning what applied to them. One employee commented, \u0026ldquo;My family is coming from a country that had a different [healthcare] system, and now I\u0026rsquo;m put into this situation where I have to figure it out on my own and I don\u0026rsquo;t have a support group to lean on.\u0026rdquo; In short, materials and websites explaining benefits need to be centralized and easy to navigate, and they also need to resonate with different audiences.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003cp\u003eEmployers can take a number of steps to improve the accessibility of employee resources and benefits, including (but not limited to) the following initiatives:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUse inclusive language\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany employees reported confusion when trying to understand which benefits they were eligible for and how to use them. Employers may consider carefully reviewing their benefits resources and ensure inclusivity in their communications. Although many of these materials are produced by health insurance companies, employers can partner with carriers to incorporate inclusive language in forms and other materials. This may include using gender-neutral language when describing parental leave or health benefits, as well as considering translating resources into a wide range of languages. Both of these steps could help ensure employees from all backgrounds have equal opportunities to understand and use their benefits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnhance the availability of personalized information\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiverse employees were especially likely to report experiencing moments of \u0026ldquo;frustration\u0026rdquo; when accessing healthcare, citing unexpected costs and \u0026ldquo;not feeling listened to\u0026rdquo; as key factors.[[footnote 10]] To help employees anticipate medical costs, employers could provide tools that estimate out-of-pocket costs for copays and deductibles. Employers could also consider implementing care-coordination services to help their employees have better healthcare experiences.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSupport through culturally competent providers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCare-coordination services guide and support employees in understanding their benefits, including estimating costs and finding providers who understand employees\u0026rsquo; backgrounds and experiences. Collectively, care coordination may improve employee experience within the healthcare system and increases the likelihood that patients receive the care they need. One Asian employee said she wanted to find doctors who would understand and not invalidate her experiences, most notably after one doctor suggested that \u0026ldquo;Asian women don\u0026rsquo;t have a high pain tolerance.\u0026rdquo; One LGBTQ+ employee discussed spending hours outside of work finding a primary care provider (PCP) who would offer a welcoming environment to their family of two moms and a child: \u0026ldquo;I didn\u0026rsquo;t want someone who would just assume my child has a dad and ask about \u0026lsquo;their father\u0026rsquo;s health history.\u0026rsquo;\u0026rdquo; Care coordinators can help employees find providers who may be better suited to their personal or economic needs, saving the employee valuable time, and helping fend off frustration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, employers can also encourage their employees to seek care from a PCP.[[footnote 11]] Employees who said they had a preferred PCP were more likely to have had \u0026ldquo;delightful\u0026rdquo; healthcare experiences; employees of color in particular were around eleven percentage points more likely to have had \u0026ldquo;delightful\u0026rdquo; experiences if they had a PCP (Exhibit 6).[[footnote 12]][[footnote 13]] LGBTQ+ employees were 30 percentage points more likely to have had \u0026ldquo;delightful\u0026rdquo; experiences. By encouraging\u0026mdash;and even providing incentives for\u0026mdash;employees to build relationships with PCPs and by giving them the needed resources to find PCPs who understand and validate personal identities and experiences, employers may be able to improve their employees\u0026rsquo; healthcare experiences, helping them receive the care they need.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 6]]\n\u003ch3\u003eBring benefits to life\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmployees could also benefit from seeing how others are actually using their benefits. HR can help by offering spotlights of real employees or employee archetypes using different benefits, including leaders with diverse profiles, in the hope that employees may identify with others who \u0026ldquo;look like them.\u0026rdquo; HR can also provide supplemental content to health insurance policies to offer more detailed guidance on the use of various benefits (for example, how to find a PCP or how to navigate a pregnancy), as well as information about how to effectively navigate the US healthcare and insurance systems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, employers can take steps to ensure that their enhanced communications are resonating with multiple audiences. These steps may include surveying employees about their experiences and conducting focus groups to further understand gaps in knowledge or understanding. HR can also partner with employee resource groups and diverse leaders to gain additional insight into preferred terminology and specific needs of diverse groups and reach out directly to specific populations that may be underusing their benefits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuild a workplace culture that destigmatizes receiving care\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen asked to describe the level of stigma in the workplace associated with taking time to address physical or mental health needs, 53 percent of all employees shared that they felt at least some degree of stigma around receiving physical care, and 61 percent noted some degree of stigma around receiving mental healthcare.[[footnote 14]] Additionally, people of color and LGBTQ+ employees were three to ten percentage points more likely to report stigma in their workplace than their White or straight counterparts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStigma is a pervasive barrier that can inhibit employees from seeking needed care. Among employees who reported not receiving the physical or mental healthcare they needed, 40 percent said the reason they did not receive care was that they felt stigma, shame, or embarrassment. People who do not receive the care they need have a higher risk of missed detection of preventable or treatable illnesses, of later-stage diagnoses, and of mortality.[[footnote 15]] Additionally, a recent survey conducted by McKinsey found that close to seven in ten respondents with high stigma levels reported missing at least a day of work because of burnout or stress.[[footnote 16]] Reducing the stigma of attending to health needs is an important component of maintaining a healthy and productive workforce.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBlack, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ employees felt particularly apprehensive about using some benefits due to worries about stigma and seeming \u0026ldquo;not committed to work.\u0026rdquo; One woman of color shared that \u0026ldquo;sometimes in a work environment you are trying to overcome a stereotype. [If you] need a break to take care of something, you are always afraid you\u0026rsquo;ll come across as lazy or be passed over for promotion.\u0026rdquo; Employees with chronic illnesses noted similar concerns and were especially worried that their health conditions would find their way into their performance reviews and affect their chances of promotion or even of keeping their job. In our survey, respondents who had missed more days of work due to their own health or that of their dependents noted higher levels of stigma.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBlack, Hispanic and Latino, and LGBTQ+ employees also noted worse mental health outcomes, likely in part due to the mental and emotional toll that stigma and biases can have.[[footnote 17]] A fifth of Black and Hispanic and Latino and a third of LGBTQ+ employees rated their mental health as \u0026ldquo;poor,\u0026rdquo; compared with one-tenth of White employees.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFostering a culture of care: Actions to consider\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhile changing a company culture to destigmatize the need for healthcare is difficult, it is a critical step in supporting health equity. Employers can consider several actions along the journey:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommunicate the importance of receiving needed care.\u003c/em\u003e Employers can start by modeling inclusive, health-centered behavior and ensuring that workplace norms support health and well-being.[[footnote 18]][[footnote 19]] For example, one company asked senior leaders to sponsor initiatives emphasizing the importance of self-care and mental health, in addition to offering additional benefits such as virtual care and on-demand apps that could provide urgent care when needed.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTrain employees on how to support one another in getting the care they need.\u003c/em\u003e By investing in employee training on topics such as mental-health first aid, employers can continue to foster workplace community and connectivity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImprove measurement and accountability.\u003c/em\u003e Employers also have an opportunity to use claims or clinical analysis, employee surveys and \u0026ldquo;pulse checks,\u0026rdquo; focus groups, lived-experience panels, and holistic assessments of their benefits and programs to monitor their progress against stated health-equity goals.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAllow for more flexible working arrangements.\u003c/em\u003e Flexible working styles can reduce stigma and improve employees\u0026rsquo; access to care.[[footnote 20]] Many focus group participants said they didn\u0026rsquo;t feel stigma while working from home during the COVID-19 pandemic because they could attend to their health needs for an hour in the middle of the day while still responding to emails and texts using their phones.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmployers can take concrete steps to achieve health equity among their employees, including making benefits easier to understand and navigate, designing new benefits to help employees meet basic needs, and developing a culture that empowers employees to seek needed care without fear of stigma. Employers have a meaningful role to play in improving the health and well-being of their employees. While health equity is first and foremost a human issue, employers that improve access to healthcare for all employees have the opportunity to make real improvements to both employee health and company performance.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-12-03T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Achieving health equity,\u0026rdquo;
